<Summary source="https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/why-halliburton-hal-49-last-earnings-report">
## Summary: Why Is Halliburton (HAL) Up 4.9% Since Last Earnings Report?

**Source:** Nasdaq (originally published by Zacks Investment Research)

---

### Recent Stock Performance
- HAL shares rose approximately **4.9%** in the month following its last earnings report, **outperforming the S&P 500** during that period.

---

### Q4 2025 Earnings Highlights
- **Adjusted EPS:** $0.69, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $0.54, though marginally down from $0.70 in Q4 2024.
- **Revenue:** $5.7 billion, up 0.8% year-over-year, beating estimates by 4.7%.
- **North American revenues:** Down 0.3% YoY to $2.2 billion (beat projections by ~$146M).
- **International revenues:** Up 1.5% YoY to $3.5 billion (beat estimates by 3%).
- **Completion & Production operating income:** $570M (vs. $629M prior year, beat estimate of $473.2M).
- **Drilling & Evaluation operating income:** $367M (vs. $401M prior year, beat estimate of $359.9M).

---

### Balance Sheet & Cash Flow
- **Cash/equivalents:** ~$2.2 billion as of Dec. 31, 2025.
- **Long-term debt:** $7.2 billion; debt-to-capitalization ratio of 40.5%.
- **Q4 free cash flow:** $875 million.
- **2025 share repurchases:** $1 billion (returning 85% of free cash flow to shareholders).
- **Capital expenditure:** $337M, below the projected $390.4M.

---

### Management Outlook
- Expects **continued strength in international business**.
- In **North America**, management anticipates the region will be "the first to respond as macro fundamentals improve," maintaining its "Maximize Value" strategy.
- Overall management tone is **confident** regarding returns and growth opportunities.

---

### Analyst Sentiment
- Estimates have been **trending upward** over the past month.
- HAL holds a **Zacks Rank #3 (Hold)**, suggesting an **in-line return** expected in the near term.
- VGM Score: **A** (Growth: B, Momentum: B, Value: B — top 40% for value investors).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/As-US-Drilling-Cools-Oilfield-Service-Firms-Chase-Middle-East-Demand.html">
## Summary: Oilfield Services Companies Pivot to Middle East as U.S. Shale Matures

**Source:** OilPrice.com, authored by Alex Kimani (described as "a veteran finance writer, investor, engineer and researcher for Safehaven.com")

---

### Key Context
- U.S. oil drilling activity has declined over 30% from late 2022 to October 2025, as mature shale basins like the Permian see declining productivity and oil executives prioritize shareholder returns over production growth.
- Major oilfield service (OFS) companies are increasingly targeting the Middle East to offset U.S. market softness.

---

### Halliburton (HAL) Specific Findings
- **Q4 2025 results** (reported January 21, 2026): Beat analyst expectations for both revenue and earnings, driven by **strong international performance** offsetting North America softness.
- Views the Middle East as a **"stable" and "durable"** market due to vast, low-cost reserves, contrasting with North American volatility.
- Focusing on **mature field development, enhanced oil recovery (EOR), and unconventional resource expansion**.
- Sees a **"huge opportunity"** in bringing U.S.-style shale efficiency gains to the Middle East.
- Acknowledges **short-term volatility** in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait activity.

---

### Broader Industry Trends Relevant to HAL
- Peers (SLB, Weatherford, Patterson-UTI, Helmerich & Payne) are all similarly pivoting Middle East strategies, suggesting **sector-wide competitive pressure** in the region.
- SLB secured a **$1.5 billion, five-year Kuwait contract**; Weatherford saw **4% sequential revenue growth** in Middle East/North Africa/Asia in Q4 2025.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.itiger.com/news/2605049360">
## Summary: Analyst Views on Halliburton (HAL) Outlook

**Source:** Tiger Brokers (via Thomson Reuters reporting); attributed analyst ratings from named institutions.

---

### Key Facts
- Halliburton **beat Q4 profit estimates**, supported by steady international market demand.
- The company **forecasts international revenue to be flat to up modestly in 2026**.
- HAL expects **2026 North America revenue to decline in the high single digits** compared to 2025.
- HAL stock was **up ~4% in 2025**.
- The company indicated it would **look to re-enter Venezuela** once commercial/legal terms (including payment certainty) are resolved.

---

### Named Analyst Opinions

| Firm | Rating | Price Target | Key View |
|------|--------|-------------|----------|
| **J.P. Morgan** | Overweight | $35 | Expects HAL top-line to decline ~2% in 2026; -7.6% North America, +1.9% international |
| **RBC Capital Markets** | Outperform | $38 | Venezuela growth is a "potential wild card"; outlook broadly in line with Street, though North America could have been better |
| **Stifel** | Buy | $36 | Expects a North America rebound in **2027** |

---

### Overall Tone
Analysts are **cautiously bearish near-term**, particularly on North America demand, while remaining moderately optimistic on international markets and longer-term recovery.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.marketbeat.com/instant-alerts/filing-halliburton-company-hal-stock-holdings-lessened-by-aberdeen-group-plc-2026-02-20/">
## Summary: Halliburton (HAL) Stock Holdings & Market Data

**Source:** MarketBeat (auto-generated narrative science article)

### Institutional Holdings Changes
- **Aberdeen Group plc** reduced its HAL stake by **20.1%** in Q3, selling 123,115 shares (retaining 489,910 shares worth ~$12M)
- Notable **increases** in holdings:
  - **Norges Bank**: New position worth ~$109.4M (Q2)
  - **AQR Capital Management**: Up 85.5% to 8.61M shares (~$175.5M)
  - **Schroder Investment Management**: Up 762.7% to 3.27M shares (~$66.5M)
  - **Pacer Advisors**: Up 23.1% to 10.15M shares (~$249.8M)
  - **Brandes Investment Partners**: Up 37.7% to 6.63M shares (~$135M)
- **85.23%** of stock owned by institutional investors

### Key Market Metrics (at time of article)
- Stock opened at **$35.32**
- 50-day moving average: **$31.69**; 200-day moving average: **$26.88**
- 52-week range: **$18.72 – $35.61**
- Market cap: **$29.58B**; P/E ratio: **23.39**; Beta: **0.77**

### Recent Earnings (Q4, reported January 21st)
- EPS: **$0.69** (beat consensus of $0.55 by $0.14)
- Revenue: **$5.66B** (beat estimates of $5.39B)
- Revenue up **0.8% YoY**; net margin: **5.78%**; ROE: **19.77%**
- Analyst consensus full-year EPS estimate: **$2.64**

### Dividend
- Quarterly dividend of **$0.17/share** (~$0.68 annualized, ~1.9% yield)
- Payable March 25th; record date March 4th; payout ratio: **45.03%**

### Analyst Ratings & Price Targets
- **BMO Capital Markets**: Raised target from $36 to **$39** ("market perform")
- **Goldman Sachs**: Raised target from $35 to **$40** ("buy")
- **Morgan Stanley**: Reissued "overweight," target **$35**
- **Jefferies**: Reissued "buy," target **$39**
- **Wall Street Zen**: Upgraded to "strong-buy"
- Consensus: **"Moderate Buy"** with average price target of **$34.95** (2 Strong Buy, 13 Buy, 8 Hold)

### Insider Activity
- **CEO Jeffrey Allen Miller** sold **171,200 shares** at ~$34.96 (Jan. 23rd) — a 13.45% reduction in his holdings
- **EVP Lawrence J. Pope** sold **100,000 shares** at ~$32.25 (Jan. 5th) — a 19.24% reduction
- Total insider sales over last 90 days: **337,002 shares worth ~$11.45M**
- Insiders own **0.56%** of stock
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://finviz.com/news/315777/why-halliburton-looks-fully-priced-after-a-65-run-in-6-months">
## Summary: "Why Halliburton Looks Fully Priced After a 65% Run in 6 Months"
**Source: Finviz / Zacks Investment Research**

### Key Facts & Statistics
- HAL shares rallied **~65% over the prior six months**, reaching a **52-week high of $35.55** in late January
- By comparison, peer **SLB gained ~55%** and **Baker Hughes ~44%** over the same period
- HAL trades at approximately **15x forward earnings**, well below the Zacks Oil & Gas Field Services industry average of **>21x**
- **North America accounts for ~40% of HAL's revenue**, with management guiding for a **high-single-digit revenue decline** in the region in 2026 (following a 6% drop in 2025)
- **Q4 revenues: $5.7 billion**; adjusted EPS: **$0.69**; operating cash flow: **$1.2 billion**
- Full-year 2025: **$2.9B operating cash flow**, **$1.9B free cash flow**; ~**85% of FCF returned to shareholders**
- **Share buybacks totaled $1 billion** in 2025, driving share count to a **decade low**
- Full-year 2025 international revenues **dipped 2%**, though this outpaced the broader decline in global rig activity
- **Zacks 2026 EPS consensus estimate** raised ~4% (from $2.18 → **$2.26**); 2027 estimate also up ~4% to **$2.65**
- HAL beat Zacks consensus estimates in **2 of the last 4 quarters**, meeting expectations in the other two, with an **average earnings surprise of ~11%**

### Analyst/Named Source Opinions
- **Zacks Investment Research** assigns HAL a **Zacks Rank #3 (Hold)**, citing solid fundamentals but a more balanced risk-reward after the strong rally
- Zacks notes the **oilfield services subindustry ranks in the top 31%** of all industries, indicating a supportive broader backdrop
- Zacks characterizes HAL as a **"wait-and-watch" name** rather than an aggressive buy at current levels

### Key Themes & Context
- Management guided for **sequential declines in both revenues and profitability in Q1 2026**, citing margin compression
- International growth drivers include **Latin America, Brazil deepwater, Guyana, and artificial lift deployments**
- HAL's shareholder return profile (buybacks + dividends) is seen as providing **stability rather than growth acceleration**
- Compared to peers, **SLB has more international exposure** and **Baker Hughes has broader LNG/subsea/energy technology exposure**, giving them different growth dynamics than HAL
- The article's central thesis: much of HAL's positive operating news is **already priced into the stock** after the 65% run, limiting near-term upside without either accelerating earnings growth or a more favorable macro backdrop
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.marketbeat.com/instant-alerts/halliburton-nysehal-reaches-new-1-year-high-following-dividend-announcement-2026-02-19/">

### Insider Activity

- Total insider sales over last 3 months: **337,002 shares** valued at ~**$11.45 million**

### Key Fundamentals

**Halliburton (NYSE:HAL) Price Target Raised to $40.00**
Halliburton (NYSE: HAL) has seen its price target raised to $40.00 by Rothschild & Co Redburn, following multiple other brokerages also increasing their targets: TD Cowen, Susquehanna, and Royal Bank of Canada all raised their price targets to $40.00, while Stifel Nicolaus set a $36.00 target. Piper Sandler increased its target to $34.00 with a 'neutral' rating. The stock currently holds a consensus rating of 'Moderate Buy' and a consensus target price of $35.19. Halliburton reported strong Q4 earnings on January 21st, posting $0.69 EPS, beating estimates of $0.55 by $0.14, and revenue of $5.66 billion, surpassing the $5.39 billion consensus. The company's revenue rose 10.8% year-over-year. Analysts project $2.64 EPS for the current fiscal year. Halliburton announced a quarterly dividend of $0.17 per share, yielding 1.9% annually, with a payout ratio of 45.03%. Insider selling has occurred recently, with Director Margaret Katherine Banks and EVP Van H. Beckwith selling shares, totaling 337,002 shares valued at $11.4 million over 90 days. Institutional investors, including Capital Research Global Investors, Vanguard Group, State Street Corp, Charles Schwab, and Northwestern Mutual Wealth Management Co., increased their stakes, with institutional ownership now at 85.23%. The company has a market cap of $29.43 billion, a P/E ratio of 23.27, a PEG ratio of 2.11, and a beta of 0.77. Its 52-week range is $18.72 to $35.85. Halliburton, founded in 1919 and headquartered in Houston, Texas, provides integrated oilfield services globally.

**Halliburton Company $HAL Stock Holdings Lessened by Aberdeen Group plc**
Aberdeen Group plc reduced its stake in Halliburton Company (NYSE:HAL) by 20.1% in the third quarter, selling 123,115 shares and leaving it with 489,910 shares, valued at $12,049,000, representing 0.06% of the company. This follows significant increases in holdings by other institutional investors: Norges Bank purchased a new position worth $109,379,000; AQR Capital Management LLC increased its stake by 85.5% to 8,610,870 shares worth $175,490,000; Schroder Investment Management Group grew its holdings by 762.7% to 3,265,132 shares valued at $66,543,000; Pacer Advisors Inc. increased its position by 23.1% to 10,154,605 shares valued at $249,803,000; and Brandes Investment Partners LP raised its stake by 37.7% to 6,625,668 shares valued at $135,031,000. Overall, 85.23% of Halliburton's stock is held by hedge funds and institutional investors. Halliburton stock closed at $35.32 on Friday, with a 50-day moving average of $31.69 and a 200-day moving average of $26.88. The company has a market cap of $29.58 billion, a P/E ratio of 23.39, a PEG ratio of 2.07, and a beta of 0.77. In its Q4 earnings report on January 21st, Halliburton reported $0.69 EPS, beating estimates of $0.55 by $0.14, with revenue of $5.66 billion versus $5.39 billion in estimates. Revenue increased 10.8% year-over-year. The company declared a quarterly dividend of $0.17, representing an annualized yield of 1.9%, with a payout ratio of 45.03%. Analysts have set a consensus price target of $34.95, with a 'Moderate Buy' rating. Price targets from major firms include $39.00 (BMO Capital Markets), $40.00 (Goldman Sachs), and $35.00 (Morgan Stanley). Insider trading activity includes CEO Jeffrey Allen Miller selling 171,200 shares at an average price of $34.96, reducing his ownership by 13.45%, and EVP Lawrence J. Pope selling 100,000 shares at $32.25, reducing his stake by 19.24%. Over the last 90 days, insiders sold 337,002 shares worth $11,445,938, representing 0.56% of the company's shares. Halliburton, founded in 1919, is a global provider of oilfield services, headquartered in Houston, Texas, with operations spanning drilling, well construction, production enhancement, and well intervention.

**HAL comes under pressure following Tejas crash at Dubai Air Show**
Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL) shares closed nearly 3% lower at Rs 4,593 following a fatal crash of a Tejas Mk-1A aircraft during the Dubai Air Show on Friday, November 21, 2025. The incident triggered immediate market concerns over the reliability, export readiness, and operational safety of India's indigenous fighter jet, despite government clarification that earlier oil leakage concerns were unfounded and unrelated to the crash. Harshal Dasani, Business Head at INVasset PMS, noted that the market reacted swiftly, as HAL’s stock had been priced for perfection, trading at elevated valuation multiples reflecting expectations of flawless execution in India’s defence manufacturing push. Although the long-term trajectory remains intact due to HAL’s record order book—including a recent mega order for 97 Tejas units and strong demand for helicopters and engines—Dasani emphasized that the crash introduces short-term reputational risk, prompting investors to reassess the risk-reward profile amid rich valuations. The crash also weighed on other defence stocks, reflecting broader market sentiment. HAL’s shares have risen nearly 1100% over the past five years, driven by strong financial performance and a robust order pipeline.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 21, 2025 02:31 PM
Source:[The New Indian Express](https://www.newindianexpress.com/business/2025/Nov/21/hal-comes-under-pressure-following-tejas-crash-in-dubai-air-show)
